name: React
description: We use React for all of our frontend projects.

name: Styled components
description: We use Styled components for styling our React apps. This allows us to reuse styles and write CSS in a way that is similar to writing React components themselves.

name: Jest
description: As the industry standard test framework for Javascript apps we use Jest to test both our backend and frontend applications. It provides an easy way to run our tests and create mocked dependencies.

name: Typescript
description:
The OP API and OA frontend are written entirely in Typescript. We are slowly migrating the OP FE from Javascript to Typescript in order to provide a better developer experience and help to reduce bugs in our code.

For new repos and code Typescript is our default language going forward

name: Microservices
description: Currently our API is a monolith app. We are already struggling with many teams commiting to the same repo and as we scale this will only increase. We will soon start splitting out microservices from our monolith API in order to start learning what this entails.

name: Cypress
description: We will use Cypress for E2E testing our applications. There is some infrastructure work needed before we can fully create an E2E test suite but once that is done it will be full speed ahead with Cypress

name: Javascript
description:
We are slowly migrating the OP FE app away from Javascript in order to provide a better developer experience using Typescript.

We will no longer be adding new Javascript to our applications

name: ExpressJS
description:
We use express as a minimalist framework to build our REST APIs on.

Our OP API is an express app wrapped in the serverless framework.

name: Auth0
description: Auth0 handles the authentication of our users and contains role information for each user which our application then uses to determine what a user can and can't do.

name: Serverless.js
description: Serverless.js is the framework we use to provision our backend infrastructure. Our OP API app is an express app 'wrapped' in the serverless framework which, using cloud formation, creates a lambda, API gateway, Databases for our app.

name: Redux
description: Redux is the global state management framework we used when first building out our OP FE application. We are now moving away from Redux towards using React-query as Redux introduces a lot of boilerplate overhead and is overkill for what we were using it for.

name: React-query
description:
React query is our go to library on the FE for handling communications with our API and managing global client side state

We are in the process of moving away from Redux and so any new features should be using React query

name: React testing library
description: React testing library is a framework we use to make testing our React application easier and the tests closer to how our users use the app in the wild.

name: AWS
description: AWS is our cloud provider where we host all of our infrastructre and application data

name: DynamoDB
description: DynamoDB is our database of choice for all OP API related data

name: EventBridge
description: EventBridge is a serverless eventbus which we use as the foundation of our event based system on the OP API

name: Storybook
description: We use storybook to display our components in a kind of catalogue to view their various states and instructions for use.

name: Mock service worker
description: Mock service worker allows us to create a stubbed service worker which we can use in tests to intercept requests and control the response our app receives when making API calls.

name: Joi
description:
Traditionally we have used Joi to validate our the requests to the API, we are moving away from this towards using Celebrate. So any new validations on the API should be using celebrate

We are still using Joi to validate our forms on the Frontend

name: Supertest
description: Test framework for E2E testing our API to use alongside Jest tests

name: Datadog
description: Datadog is an observability service for cloud-scale applications, providing monitoring of servers, databases, tools, and services, through a SaaS-based data analytics platform. Notion Page

name: Sentry
description: Sentry monitors our front end application Notion Page

name: CircleCI
description: CircleCi is our go to CI/CD pipeline which tests and deploys our code on every push to the Github repo

name: Celebrate
description: Celebrate is a middleware based validation library which wraps the Joi validation library, we are moving away from vanilla Joi to using Celebrate for our BE validation.

name: Sonarcloud
description: SonarCloud is our much loved static code quality service. Notion Page

name: Github
description: Our Github repro houses all our production code

name: Design system
description: In order to keep our components and styling consistent across our apps and speed up development of new features we will be looking at creating a design system which can be used across FE apps

name: Microfrontends
description: Currently our OP FE is a monolith app. We are already struggling with many teams commiting to the same repo and as we scale this will only increase. We also have different security needs for our different apps/user types and so we will start to investigate how we could move to a microfrontend approach for our frontend apps.

name: Contentful
description: We use contentful as the backing CMS for all of our country specific data.

name: Continuous delivery
description: Continuous delivery is a software engineering approach in which teams produce software in short cycles, ensuring that the software can be reliably released at any time and, when releasing the software, without doing so manually. It aims at building, testing, and releasing software with greater speed and frequency.

name: Zapier
description: We use Zapier as an automation workflow tool, we trigger Zapier webhooks through our API. We can then configure automated workflows that respond to a specific webhook being triggered. This is useful when integrating with external systems that we aren't ready to fully integrate into the platform.

name: Feature flags
description: We use feature flags to separate the release of features to customers from deployment of our code which allows us to get closer to true trunk based development and ship small slices of value

name: Lighthouse
description: Light House is an open-source, automated tool for improving the quality of web pages. Notion Page

name: Axe
description: Axe Core is an accessibility testing engine for websites and other HTML-based user interfaces. Notion Page

name: BrowserStack
description: Testing on 3000+ real devices and browsers. Webpage

name: Product Element Maps
description: It is an artefact (a map, or list, or tableâ€¦) that identifies the dimensions or elements of a product. Notion Page

name: Exploratory Testing
description: Exploratory testing is an approach to software testing that is concisely described as simultaneous learning, test design and test execution. Notion Page

name: RiskStorming
description: RiskStorming is a collaborative exercise that focuses on identifying risks that impact the quality aspects of your product and helps you to mitigate them. Notion Page

name: Testing Quadrants
description: They are a framework for thinking about, and discussing, what types of testing might be needed. Different tests have different purposes and the quadrants allow us to think more holistically about software testing. Notion Page

name: Quality Culture Transition Guide
description: A guide to help teams and departments move towards a quality culture

name: Four key metrics
description:
To measure software delivery performance, more and more organizations are turning to the four key metrics as defined by the DORA research program: change lead time, deployment frequency, mean time to restore (MTTR) and change fail percentage. This research and its statistical analysis have shown a clear link between high delivery performance and these metrics; they provide a great leading indicator for how a team, or even a whole delivery organization, is doing.

We're still big proponents of these metrics, but we've also learned some lessons since we first started monitoring them. And we're increasingly seeing misguided measurement approaches with tools that help teams measure these metrics based purely on their continuous delivery (CD) pipelines. In particular when it comes to the stability metrics (MTTR and change fail percentage), CD pipeline data alone doesn't provide enough information to determine what a deployment failure with real user impact is. Stability metrics only make sense if they include data about real incidents that degrade service for the users.

And as with all metrics, we recommend to always keep in mind the ultimate intention behind a measurement and use them to reflect and learn. For example, before spending weeks to build up sophisticated dashboard tooling, consider just regularly taking the DORA quick check in team retrospectives. This gives the team the opportunity to reflect on which capabilities they could work on to improve their metrics, which can be much more effective than overdetailed out-of-the-box tooling.

name: The ten P's of Testability
description: They are a way of thinking about the testability of a product from people to production Notion Page

name: Visual Task Analysis
description: Is a fairly new approach to help visualise the types of tests you might need across your product and how to mitigate those risk using the layers of your architecture as a guide Notion Page

name: Scope Discovery and Alignment (ScoDA)
description: A meeting format that is designed to help with Scope (information), Discovery (Questions | Answers), and Alignment (Understanding) Notion Page

name: Modern Testing Principles
description: A set of principles to guide modern testing practices.

name: Retrospectives
description: We value the opportunity to learn and adapt

name: Blameless Postmortems
description: The goal of a blameless post-mortem is to discover what happened in an incident, to understand how to prevent a similar incident from happening in the future. Notion Page

name: Postman
description: Postman is a API platform for building and using API's Notion Page

name: Test-driven development (TDD)
description: Test Driven Development (TDD) is software development approach in which test cases are developed to specify and validate what the code will do. In simple terms, test cases for each functionality are created and tested first and if the test fails then the new code is written in order to pass the test and making code simple and bug-free.

name: Guilds | Communities of Practice
description: Communities of practice (Guilds) regularly bring together people who share areas of interest or concerns. They are loose structures that support their members and the organisation's development of those areas. Notion Page

name: Tableau
description: Tableau helps people see and understand data

name: Snowflake
description: Snowflake is your solution for data warehousing, data lakes, data engineering, data science, data application development, and securely sharing and consuming shared data.

name: Airflow
description: Airflow is a platform created by the community to programmatically author, schedule and monitor workflows.

name: CASL
description: We use CASL for our auth middleware on the BE to help with RBAC and ensure our users are authorised for the action they are attempting to take

name: AWS API gateway
description: We use AWS API gateway to expose our lambda API to the internet and provide a singe endpoint for our FE to interact with. In the future we will use an API gateway as teh entry point to our mesh of microservices.
